description:
Trivia game with more than 200 questions about coffee, cultivation, roasting, different types of coffee and more. Players choose for each question how many points they want to make and how big a risk they are willing to take.

Aim of the game: Having the highest number of points after a certain number of question cards have been played (number to be decided by the players at the beginning of a game). Points are earned by correctly answering questions.

Gameplay: The starting player takes a card from the card stack, chooses a letter and reads the corresponding question and its answers. There are two types of questions:

- Questions with one to three correct answers: For each question, there are four answers. One to three of them are correct, at least one is wrong. When all the answers have been read, the players place their chip(s) on the betting boards for the answer(s) that they think is/are correct. Each player (including the one who read the question) can place up to three chips. Players who put their chips on one or more wrong answers don't get any points this round. Players with exactly one correct answer get to advance their pawn one space, 2 correct answers means advancing 2 spaces, 3 correct answers 3 spaces.

- Questions whose answers have to be put in the correct order: For each question, there are three answers. When all the answers have been read, players put their chips in the order that they think is correct (the chips are numbered 1-3 on one side). Players with all three chips in the correct order advance three spaces. Players with one correct answer advance one space.

The Deck of Change is a deck of 64-cards with 8 numbers and 8 symbols. It is an open game system designed primarily for fun. It is versatile, multipurpose, and mathematically satisfying to play around with.

These cards might just bring out the most fun you can ever have with your  family, friends, and even strangers. Kids from age 7 to 107 can enjoy the different games for 1 to 16 players. The deck has 64 cards, 8 numbers (0-7), and 8 symbols (yin, energy, force, space, matter, entropy, time, yang).

There are 3 versions of the deck. They are practically the same deck. The main difference is in the visuals. Deck #1: The AiTiA is designed for functionality. Deck #2: The Gauntlet is designed for imagination featuring artwork by Patrick Enrique. And, Deck #3: The Cauldron has bigger cards designed for creativity and brainstorming.

Goal is for players to earn as many segments and units as possible and to have the most money on their money tracking card at the end of game play. Player rolls dice and subtracts one from the other, lands on a given segment and must answer a question from a given math strand if they want to gain credit for that segment. Once a segment is owned, player receives a card showing him/her the fees involved when someone else lands on that segment. All fees are derived from different mathematical questions that are related to the name of the segment owned.
Mathopoly offers students the opportunity to learn mathematical concepts and formulas in a fun, relaxed environment.  Mathopoly the math game incorporates the mathematical diversity required to ensure success for kids in today’s challenging curriculum.

Not Under My Roof! is a fast-paced fighting game in which opponents battle their way through a building. Rather than sitting at a table, the cards you play knock your opponent from room to room until somebody is tossed through an exit. Some cards work better if an object like a lamp or TV is in the room with you. You will fight through the building until somebody throws you out and yells NOT UNDER MY ROOF!
(From The Game Crafter page)

"Gamer Geeks, this game is going to rip you a new one, in a good way!" - Father Geek

"Overall, this game is just phenomenal. It brings a fresh type to the table top and hours of replayability. I cannot wait to be playing the finished product in my living room." - Demo Player Richard Nava

"I'm not a game player in general and I was surprised how much I got into (Specimen), playing the first time. I was PISSED when my flamethrower was going to be used against me. PISSED. And I was thrilled for the player next to me when she went for a move that was balls out ballsy…these guys are the real deal…FUN STUFF, FOLKS!" - Demo Player Rebecca L

SPECIMEN is a two-player card-driven board game that pits a group of human astronauts against a predatory extraterrestrial life form.

Each turn comprises four action rounds, where each player can perform one of several possible game actions. The Monster's movements are hidden from the Crew player behind a game screen, and the Monster's location is only revealed when the Monster attacks...or if the crew is lucky (or unlucky) enough to find it!

At the beginning of play, a mysterious specimen in the cargo hold has been let loose as a result of the damage caused by a meteor collision. This SPECIMEN is in an embryonic stage and evolves throughout the game, becoming more difficult to kill as the turns progress. In addition to attempting to kill the crew, the monster can also destroy sections of the ship, forcing the human players to divide their efforts between defense and structural repair. The monster can win the game by either killing all seven members of the crew or damaging enough sections of the ship that it breaks apart. Adding the destruction of the ship as an alternate victory condition allows for varied strategies on the part of both players. The human player can use tools to effect repairs, construct weapons and trackers to hunt down the monster…or ultimately blow up the ship if all seems lost.

The SPECIMEN player constructs his/her monster from a selection of 25 different attributes (offensive, defensive, or special abilities), providing new and different threats to the human player each game. This constantly changing monster, combined with 90 event cards driving game play, allows for infinite replayability. No two games should ever be the same.

Power Lines is a tile laying game for PiecePack in which players take turns placing tiles from a communal pool. One player is attempting to create rows, columns, or diagonals in which there are a majority of matching suits, while the opposing player is doing the same except for matching values.

When the 4x4 grid has been fully filled in, players score points for rows, columns, or 4-tile diagonals in which they have the largest matching set.

Although originally designed for the PiecePack game system, Power Lines is playable with a standard deck of playing cards.

For each game another Fun Park in Austria is selected as final destination and each player chooses a city where he wants to start. Then each player receives 5 city cards, these cities the player must visit on this way from start to finish. The roll of the die determines how many cities can be visited in one turn, a "6" allows to fly to any city. If a player passes through or reaches one of his cities, he may discard the corresponding card. The first player to reach the Fun Park without any city cards wins the game.

Building towers, or rather build one tower by a joint effort. Who manages to place the roof or place the last block? The game is directed by cards. On a square basis area the triangular basis block is set up. The cards are stacked. In your turn you reveal the top building card - the cards determine which block must be placed with which hand. There are also cards offering free choice or change of turn order or cards demanding placement of a roof. If you can place a roof or the last block without tumbling the tower you receive a chip. If you collect three chips you win the game.

German card game. 31 cards. Each card has three types of train;
Personenzug = Local train
Eilzug = Fast train
D - Zug = Very fast train

Underneath each designation there is the name of a city which will have a railway station.

The game plays a little like Rummy in that you are trying to lay down sets of cities that are linked by one of the three train types. In other words, a train route.

First to play all their cards wins.

I think this must have required seriously good knowledge of trains and their destinations. I mean, is it likely that someone living in Hamburg would know a local train route around Munich? Perhaps it was only aimed at keen railway fans.

A quiz in the form of a fan, on the subject of dinosaurs, 1000 questions and answers sequenced by time periods. The cards are held by a screw and can be ideally taken on travels, the answers are always on the next page. The quiz can be played alone or by several players.

A religious question and answer game, probably intended for Sunday Schools in East Germany in the fifties.
Contents: 20 Playing Boards + 96 Question and answer cards.

Up to 20 players get a board with 4 different chapters of the Bible. Every board is different.

The players (or teacher) take turns to read out one of the 96 Question cards. If another player thinks he recognises that scripture is one of his four chapters on his board, he can say the answer. If he is right he gets to keep the card and places it on the appropriate space on his board. If he is wrong, other players can guess if they want.
The first player to get all four chapters on his board covered, wins

The heart of the game are 55 double-sided cards, thus presenting 110 important phrases, words or questions, specially geared to holiday needs and packed separately in a plastic box for easy transport. A ring-track on the board shows empty spots and spots with city names. Players roll the die and move their token, if it lands on a city name the player can try to translate one card. It the translation is correct he receives one chip. The first player to collect 5 chips wins the game.

The training box stands upright, the colour chips fall down, then the box is placed horizontally again. One learning table is chosen and is slid into the box. The child must find the colour corresponding to the correct solution for the task and move a colour chip with the magnetic pencil onto the solution spot of the board. To check for correct solution one pulls out the board and turns it over and slides it back in, the colour spots now must correlate with the colour chips.

Start up your engine, find the ideal track and leave your opponents behind. Follow the Golden Line to victory. This game simulates real speedway races and lets you and your fellow players to take part in nerve-wracking races in the comfort of home. Experience not only the ride, but also what it is to set up a bike for a race. Faithful models of motorcycles move around the track without frames and the help of an ingenious distance gauge. Bikes perform the classic speedway skid when going around corners. The speed of motorbikes depends on their position on the oval as well as the tuning of the motorcycle and chance, as decided on the throw of a dice. Chance alone, however, is not enough to win; you have to be able to tell when luck will help a bit and some healthy risk-taking is required, and when it is better to step on the gas. The game can be enjoyed with children and friends

Cavemen: The Quest for Fire is a card-drafting game in which players take the role of tribal leaders. The tribes compete for opportunities to hunt dinosaurs, recruit tribesmen, and discover new technologies, vying to be the first with enough knowledge and prestige to invent fire and usher in the age of modern humanity!

You have two resources to manage: Food and Teeth.  You must spend Food each turn in order to keep your Tribe from starving.  Teeth indicate prestige among the tribes.  Use Teeth to bid for the conch and to acquire Cavemen and Caves.

Each turn, cards are drawn from the deck to fill a common Card Pool.  Players take actions based on what is available in the pool.  For example, if a Beast is drawn into the Card Pool, you can hunt it for Food and claim its Teeth as a sign of your bravery.

If you hold the conch during the Action Phase, you benefit by taking your Action first and taking a second Action after everyone else has gone once.  Players can bid Teeth to take control of the Conch from another player.  This can be important to get the first pick of the cards in the Card Pool.

The game features 21 different inventions that allow players to evolve diverse strategies, capitalizing on their tribe's individual strengths. There are challenging decisions every turn as players must evaluate what resources are available, guess what their opponents will do, and weigh the amount of risk they're willing to take.

Bassin’ Cards is an educational bass tournament card game for 1-5 anglers.  The object of the game is to catch the heaviest total weight of bass in a 1, 2, or 3 day fishing tournament.  Playing time varies with number of players & days fished.  Two players, fishing a two-day tournament, would take approximately 1 hour.
In this game, players place cards to set up areas to fish based on what lures are in their tackle boxes, and what presentations they can use.  As you play, you will learn the best techniques and fishing strategies under different external conditions.
The winner will be the one who can catch the heaviest stringer of fish when the tournament is over.

It's showtime! Angelina Ballerina is the star of the show and guess who she wants on stage too - YOU! Practice the moves step-by-step - every time you play it's a whole new ballet routine! When it's showtime, turn on the music and take center stage!

Players take turns spinning the spinner, collecting star cards and moving Angelina along the board rehearsing for her recital. When she reaches the It's Showtime! space each player has to try to perform the recital from memory. The player with the most star cards of the same color wins!

In the early months of 1943, the United States and British Commonwealth forces had finally defeated Rommel and the axis armies of North Africa. The allied leaders were in disagreement on what the next step should be; invade Italy, the Balkans, or France. Stalin was desperate to open another front in Europe. Churchill wanted to invade Italy which he labeled “the soft underbelly of the Axis”. It was agreed that since no invasion of Northern France could be undertaken in 1943, that the invasion of Sicily would take place. The allied commanders were sure that invading Italy would all but destroy the Italians will to fight, and maybe the government and Mussolini would be overthrown.

The German high command was also aware that Italy’s support for the war was dwindling. German units that were needed for the Eastern front were sent to Italy to help defend against an allied attack and to police the Italian army in case of a coup. With most of Germany’s army and supplies on the Eastern front and a weakening ally in Italy, Germany is desperate to keep the allies out of Southern Europe.

The Invasion of Italy is an Axis & Allies style game that puts you in the seat of the Axis commanders who are racing to get their army into a position to defend Southern Europe, and Allied commanders who are ready to open another front in Europe to relieve the Russians on the Eastern front. Will you follow history as the allies and invade Sicily and then Italy, or will you try to take Rome first and severe the Axis army in Europe? Can the Axis hold out long enough with their limited supplies, or will Italy fall and leave Germany defending Italy…..ALONE?

The game features a map of Italy (36" x 48")(91 cm x 122 cm) divided into controllable territories. One player plays the side of the Axis controlling the Italian and German units defending Italy against the Allied Invasion. The other player controls the Allies who have 20 turns to take as many victory cities as possible before the Germans can reinforce Italy. Game uses a D12 combat system and pieces from the Axis & Allies series of games and is a variant of these games.

The Game comes with map , rules, and some units. You will need additional pieces to play the game.

A game for all friends of dinosaurs. The game holds 600 questions and answers on the subject, players try to win colourful dinosaur disks. A special point of interest are the short descriptions of more than 70 dinosaur varieties, including info text and 6 questions. The rule gives 2 game variants.

The topic chips for human - natural - heavenly - terrestrial are sorted and laid out as stated in the rules, as are the randomly chosen and shuffled obstacle tiles. These obstacles can only be mastered by discarding of topic chips. The questions cards are sorted in order of the topics, but if so desired can be shuffled.

In your turn you are the questioner, you draw the front card and name the topic, the facts, the questions and all answers. Then all players in turn choose and name one of the answers. Then the correct answer is read. If you answered correctly you can either move your pawn or take a corresponding topic chip from stock. If you reach a face-down topic chip first, you get it. If all answer wrong, the questioner gets a chip. If you answer correctly "all wrong", you move one step and get a chip. A spot containing an obstacle tile may only be entered if you can discard 2 corresponding topic chips. The rules also provide for players who have dropped back very far.

Objective: Try to (visit and) solve as many accidents as possible - collecting points/acting by turns

1 There are accidents - spread all over the board 
2 If your die shows a 'five' - your car may start
3 Choose a route on which you can solve these accidents as quick as possible
3 Game ends if the last accident was followed up

Objective: Be the first to move your car over the finish line
(field 90)
Simple 'roll and move' GDR game learning traffic signs and rules
as typical for comparable products: Individual meeples (cars) and detailed coloured map

Objective:
Be the first to reach target line
Typical 'roll and move' game before WW I. 
Very nice drawings/printing and  - of course - pewter pawns
Rules inside cover

Artist:
Emil Heinsdorff

remark: This game belongs to the series:
"Scholz künstlerische Spiele" - 2 different product codes

A nice and handy gimmick vaguely looking like a smiling face is filled with cardbord discs on which questions and answers are printed. All discs are shuffled and inserted into the gimmick. Then the child turns the "nose" on the front of the "Questioner" until the question can be read in the window. Then the child answers, using one of the choices given, and remembers the number next to his chosen answer. When he lifts the Question Mark, the number visible underneath shows the correct answer. The questions are sorted into three different grades of complexity, marked with 1, 2 or 3 stars. The question must be positioned exactly in its window to have the correct answer appear in the answer window. A nicely done and well working quiz and learning game, working well as a solitary game.

In this game, players alternate taking the role of the fish, and the other try to find the optimum pattern to catch him. Players get 100 practice casts trying to discover the best pattern before the 20 cast tournament. After each tournament, players are scored for how they did.  Players fish in real time at their own pace. 
After everyone has a chance at being the elusive bass, the scores are added up and a winner is determined.

In the adventure, you and your friends (tha' be players later on) take on the roles of legendary privateers, shrewd buccaneers and other kinds of bloodthirsty scallywags. All of whom are tied together by the code and honour amongst pirates.
Both code and honour will be betrayed multiple times as the players plot and make mischief for and against each other. One adventure takes approximately one to two hours, including all preparations and planning, such as shuffling the cards, creating characters and making up the premise. The game is playable with just the cards, but you might find the game easier to follow if you use paper to make notes and count the crosses in the Davy Jones Counter. The game is all about having fun. Push your characters into complicated and fun situations. Curse like a scallywag. Cheat fate, act like a legend, and if the inevitable cold grave calls you - go with a bang.

Each player has a character. After creating the characters, you may use the cards and the adventure-o-matic to create a grand,
challenging adventure. All scenes start from a plot twist. The twists might be positive, helpful, funny or they might come in the shape of a challenge. Players respond to challenges by using cards from their hand. A player may play as many cards of the same suit as he likes, but the sum of their values must be at least equal to the challenge card’s value in order to beat the challenge. If the character is unable to resolve a challenge with the cards in hand, the situation might call for a betrayal. A challenge from another character’s action can kill a character, if the challenge winning player calls for it. However, challenges between characters do not need to be deadly: a character might try to seduce another or steal his hat.

Pirates never betray each other, or the pirate code, Well... at least if it’s not a matter of life and death ... Or if it’s not about love ... Or if there is no gold in it ... Or… well, you get the picture. A player calls for a betrayal, and asks for a suit. Even if the characters cannot die directly from the challenges, there is a price for failure and betrayal. Sooner or later the cold arms of the grave will welcome all pirates of the sea. There should be 12 empty slots in each character sheet. These slots are used to keep score of the character’s failures and betrayals. Each time the character fails a challenge, two X’s are added to the counter.
Each time the character betrays the others, one X is added to the counter.

And each time the character gets one or more X’s - a card is drawn. If the value of the card is equal or less than the number of X’s on the character sheet, the character’s days are numbered and he is doomed.If a character already has 12 X’s on the sheet, he is immediately doomed, when he gets the 13th mark.
A doomed character will die in any of the next three scenes. Players should not feel too attached to a doomed character. He might look pale or even ghostly or see omens of his death for he knows that the day is his last.

When and how does the game end?
The game should end if
• Adventure has reached its conclusion,
• You reach agreed time limit (Professional pirates recommend using 2 hour time limit)
• Players are too tired (of drinking Rum) to play on.

In #OccupyBoardwalk, players take the role of the 1% trying to retain control of the board against increasing demonstrations against their rule. The goal is to be the player with the most money at the end of the game, assuming the 99% don’t successfully occupy too much of your precious property! If that happens, everyone loses.


    OccupyBoardwalk is an Uncooperative Game for 3 or More Players. It just requires a copy of Monopoly and a book. (It can be any book, but we suggest Das Capital, Road to Serfdom or a pocket copy of the Constitution).  


Each round, the public expects the 1% to pay another 1000 dollars of your fortunes towards the public good. To do this, the player with the Top Hat opens the book to a page an puts any amount of money into the book secretly. They then flip to another page and pass the book to the next player. When a player gets the book, they can’t flip backwards in the book to see what other players have payed. Once each player has had an opportunity to put money into the book, the first player turns the book over and shakes it over the board. Collect the money that falls out, count it and put it under public parking.

Remember two things: The player with the most money left at the end of the game wins. Also, the public expects the 1% to pay another $1000 every turn. So the expectations of the public about the amount of money in public parking increases every turn. There are a few other twists and turns involving the removal of protestors from properties, and the use of Chance and Community Chest cards to get bailed out when things get rough. The full rules are available in the attachments or at the link provided in the link section

"Hamsterdam is the best dam game around."

"The flood waters are piling up and the noblest of creatures are all that remain to protect us."

How to play: 
Create a "dam" made up of a line of cards numbered 2 through 12 and distribute your hamster cards (20 regular + 2 special) on top of the numbered cards.  Take turns rolling the dice to see which spot in the damn is weakened.  If a hamster is on top of that number, that hamster is used to plug to the hole and is placed to the side in a reserve pile to come back into play in the next round.  If a hamster is not on that number, a flood token is placed there until the end of the round, at which time it can be removed by taking a hamster card permanently out of play.  If a flood token is already located on a number that is rolled, another flood token is placed in a special pile of tokens belonging to that player which cannot be removed.  As flood tokens pile up, your stock of hamster saviors dwindles, and flood tokens pile up all the faster.  The game ends when any player accumulates 10 flood tokens (counting both those in the permanent pile and those currently on the dam).  The winner is the player with the fewest flood tokens.  In the case of a tie, the player with the most remaining hamster cards wins.

The year is 2164. Mankind has self-actualized enough to realize that we are creatures of violence. Centuries of denying one of our base instincts has not led to a more civilized society. Technological advances have given unprecedented scales of damage potential to our conflicts. In 2153, the Council of Restraint was formed in response to the particularly devastating aftermath of a conflict between the United African Republic and Pacific Rim Conglomerate. Three years later the Conflict Resolution Accords were ratified. Now when conflicts arise, the involved states or ideological groups can settle the dispute in a manner that mitigates widespread destruction. Large, mechanized military machines meet to do battle of epic proportion. These battles are waged in controlled arenas to contain the violence and damage. Armored Terran Systems Corporation manufactures base machines called Mechs and combatants configure their Mech with armaments and options in preparation for combat.

The Earth Shook is a game where each player assumes the role of a large mechanized military class robot. Where man once waged war across the globe on epic proportions, machines now resolve the conflict in controlled arenas. Build your machine, defend your ideology, and destroy the others. Be the last machine standing on the field of battle; to the victor go the spoils of war.

Players each receive a basic identical Mech from the factory. They have a set amount of points that they can use to buy modules for the Mech. These modules adjust the ratings for Evasion, Shields, Armor, Speed, Maneuverability, Weapon Damage, Rate of Fire, and more. Once the modules have been purchased, the Mech stats are adjusted to reflect the module choices and teh game can commence.

Game play is similar to RoboRally or Wings of War in that each player will select 6 Move/Maneuver actions for their Mech each turn. In this manner, a turn is played out in six rounds as the Mechs execute their programmed moves. Can you out-maneuver your opponent? Do you risk an all out frontal attack. Each player will approach the battle differently, hoping to draw upon the strengths of their configured Mech.

Build & Battle. The game is on...

Trivia game about Austria.
The game consists of 240 questions on 48 cards, in the categories Town and Country, Art and Culture, History and Modern Times, Food and Drinks, Sports, Leisure and Holiday as well as Demands, 5 questions and 1 demand per cards, in varying sequences. Correct answers ears souvenirs, demands must be fulfilled when possible and change ownership of souvenirs. One can only hold a limited number of souvenirs of a kind, or must exchange them. Whoever has the most souvenirs at the end of the game wins.

Trivia game about Spain.
The game consists of 240 questions on 48 cards, in the categories Town and Country, Art and Culture, History and Modern Times, Food and Drinks, Sports, Leisure and Holiday as well as Demands, 5 questions and 1 demand per cards, in varying sequences. Correct answers ears souvenirs, demands must be fulfilled when possible and change ownership of souvenirs. One can only hold a limited number of souvenirs of a kind, or must exchange them. Whoever has the most souvenirs at the end of the game wins.

Knights and ghost hold a race on the sides of the box, in the bottom of the box the castle is put over one of the quiz pages, windows of the castle show 4 correct and 4 wrong answers to the question on top of the page. Depending on the roll of the die one may move knight or ghost or put a chip on a correct answer. Can be played by one person alone.

A trump and guessing game on 32 kinds of predators, the cards show a number range, the name of the animal, the size and weight of the animal, the kind of protection it is awarded and the feed of the animal. The cards are dealt, in his turn a player rolls the die and depending on the roll he chooses a very big or a very small number from the information on his cards, the next player answers with his biggest or smallest number in the same category. The player with the highest or lowest number respectively wins both cards. If one player has run out of cards, the player with the most cards wins. Packed in a belt bag, with a predator tooth on a cord.

Opération Husky, Sicile 1943 (Operation Husky, Sicily 1943) covers, for two players, the campaign for Sicily in 1943 on a map divided in zones.

Scale:
- One turn for 3 to 5 days
- Units are divisions (with some regiment and brigade for special cases)

Scenarios:
- One historical campaign game
- One "what if?" scenario featuring an alternate landing zone.

The game uses classical principal with in addition GQ support, random events and optional rules.

It includes:
- A3 map
- 101 die cut counters
- rule and scenario booklet

Available with French rules, but English rules can be downloaded from Vae Victis website.

Memeopoly is a fun social drinking game which isn't complicated and doesn't require you to memorize or agree upon the rules.
The object of the game is simply to have fun with your friends and have a few drinks. You are able to quantify a victory by choosing to play with certain rules.

				
				
					How to play:
         Draw a card.
         Do what the card says.
         Discard the card.
         Next Player’s turn.
    


The game ends when you run out of cards or find a special “Win” card near the end of the deck.
The text on the cards range from taking drinks, listing categories of objects, attempting physical feats, speaking in funny accents and deck manipulation.

There are several different ways to play including mechanics of hand management, point accumulation and just playing for the sake of playing the different cards.

				
				
					Game details:
    Players 3-10.
    Age Range: Drinking age and upwards.
    Duration: 30min to 2hrs depending on player count and number of cards.
    Complexity: Easy to play, no complicated rules. Remove certain cards to customize gameplay.
    Decks: Available in decks of 52 cards, every card is unique with a unique rule. Currently two decks are available.


				
				
					More info:You can try the game, download the print and play version of the game for free, or purchase a deck from games official website.

This in an educational game from Brasil. The child attempts to match images of fruits and vegetables by combining two beautifully illustrated cards. Each card contains 50% of the object and 50% of the name.

The cards fit together like two halves of a puzzle to form a complete image, so the child learns by trial and error as the game progresses.

A successful match helps the child learn the word for the object and teaches the child how the fruit or vegetable appears in the natural world.

Includes 22 cards, rules, and a storage insert.

A solitaire option is available.

The 4th Indian Division assault on Halfaya Pass during Operation Battleaxe, June 15-16 1941


Halfaya Pass is another small GSI offering. The game focuses on tactical level combat and maneuver during Operation Battleaxe prior to the Crusader operation that lifted the seige of Tobruk. This is a stand alone game and does not need any other GSI title to be played.  It is slightly larger than Hafid Ridge in terms of the number of units and can be played in a relatively short time.The rules are modeled around the seven battlefield operating systems which make them easily understood and easy to learn.

This battle will provide a challenge to both players.  The British will find that they need to be very aggressive to push through the anti-tank defense.  The Germans have to simply hang on.  Either way it's a cliff hanger.  The British Matilda's are the queen of the battlefield, until they meet the 88's.  Obstacle play is important and significant.

Game play is excellent for solitaire play and moves along very quickly. The game is specifically designed to play in a day.

The Commonwealth forces were made up of 3 infantry battalions and a squadron and a half of Matilda tanks, heavy but undergunned and underpowered.

This game focuses on company / platoon combat and combined arms use. The time scale is either 1 or 2 hours per turn and each hex is 330 meters, depending on the game.

This game comes with:

    (2) 11x17 Color Map Sections
    (1) Color Order of Battle Card
    Approximately 200 Double-sided and Die Cut Counters


(from box and publisher's website)

"Collect, Stretch & Destroy!"

Battle Bands is a collectible elastic band game where players build armies and take turns flicking them at a board. When two opposing bands touch, they "battle" using the corresponding character cards to see who wins. The game ends when all players have depleted their armies,and the points are tallied based on where their bands are on the board.

The elastic bands are shaped like different creatures, and come in red, blue and green. Each elastics' corresponding card has a strength level for the creature, and players build armies up to a certain level (for example, if they are "brawling, each player's army will consist of creatures totaling a strength of 50).

In addition, each player may add one black elastic band to their army. These black creatures have special abilities which will affect the board.

The game draws heavily from Magic: The Gathering for theme, and from Heroscape for building your army of bands.

Players play as snakes competing to collect eggs scattered across the board. Every time you eat an egg, your snake grows longer. Watch out, though; snakes can eat each other's tails, so a long snake is a tempting target!

Points are awarded for eating eggs and other snake's tails. A balance of both is usually needed to win.

Puz-L-Game is basically a 21" x 14" puzzle divided into four color-coded triangle sections.  The instructions for the game are printed in the center of the puzzle on a 24-piece white oval.  They instruct 2, 3, or 4 players to each collect one color-coded section of the puzzle (96 pieces) prior to the game beginning.  Then players compete to see who can complete their section of the puzzle first.  There are two themes I am aware of: African Animals and Race Cars.  The African Animals Puz-L-Game consists of a blue rhino, a red elephant, a yellow lion, and a green gorilla

Animal Upon Animal: Crest Climbers uses the same basic gameplay as Animal Upon Animal: Each turn a player rolls the die and either places one or two animals on to the stack of animals, passes one of their animals to another player for them to place, or places an animal on the table, extending the base for other players to build upon. Of course, if any pieces fall off whilst you are building, you get up to two of them back. The first player to have used all of their animals wins.

Animal Upon Animal: Crest Climbers, first released as Tier auf Tier: Gipferstürmer, features animals and objects native to Switzerland.

A game to help 'Tiny Tots' to recognise names and objects. A question sheet is laid over the mechanics. On the left there are 3 pictures per line, making 12 pictures altogether per sheet. On the right are 12 boxes with the names of the objects. A child must touch an object with the lead and then touch the name. If correct, bulbs will light up.
When played competitively, the first one to get a pre-set number of questions right, wins.

Middle-earth Play-By-Mail is an award-winning strategic game set the world of J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth. In it, you take on the role of the heroes (and villains) of Middle-earth, leading armies, undertaking perilous adventures, governing your cities and towns, and making all the decisions that affect your empire.

Middle-earth Play-By-Mail is a team game, where you work together as part of either the Free Peoples in defending the innocent against Sauron's hatred, or as a Dark Servant, a hand of Sauron.

Middle-earth Play-by-Mail is a turn-based game. This means that rather than playing online, you have the luxury of time in which to consider and plan your next move, before submitting your new orders.

A STORYTELLING BOARD GAME SET IN THE 1970s COLD WAR ERA.

SMERSH is a portmanteau of two Russian words that translates to "Death to Spies."  It operated as a counter-intelligence agency by the Red Army during the 1940s. Despite having had a large number of paid employees, little was known about the agency until recently when Russia opened their archives.

Agents of SMERSH is a cooperative Storytelling game that pits players as UN Secret Service Spies set in an alternate 1970s timeline against a newly formed and independent SMERSH. Agents of SMERSH includes custom dice to determine success or failure of encounters,  and more strategic play from what is typically expected of a Storytelling board game.  There are plenty of James Bond gadgets, guns, cars, pop references and detailed artwork - not to mention a touch of humor.  The game features the artwork of George Patsouras (The Resistance & Flash Point).

The game is able to accommodate play with either The Encounter Book, which contains over 1500 written encounters with a similar reaction matrix to Tales of the Arabian Nights -  or played more simply with only encounter cards with shorter encounters and no matrix. The First Edition (2012) of the game came with the Encounter Cards as standard, and the Encounter Book as an optional add-on (although many copies did actually include the book). The Second Edition (2015) includes the Encounter Book as standard, with the Encounter Cards available to purchase from the publisher.
A simple race game. Throw dice and move, and obey any instructions

WELCOME TO DARK MOON. The Noguchi Masaki interplanetary mining corporation welcomes you to its outpost on Titan, the dark moon of Saturn! You will be joining an experienced crew of miners, technicians, and adventurous souls who live to experience all the wonders that our solar system has to offer. Purpose, loyalty, camaraderie, friendship, and sacrifice all await you as a new and valued member of the Noguchi Masaki family!

DARK MOON (formerly known as BSG Express), is a game of deception and betrayal at the cold edge of space.
 You are a crew member on a deep space mining expedition to Titan, the dark moon of Saturn. During a routine excavation, an “incident” occurs whereby some of the crew become infected with an unknown virus, and become paranoid, deceitful, and violent, trying to destroy the others.

At the start of the game, players are divided into two teams: Uninfected and Infected. The Uninfected team simply needs to survive until the end of the game, while the Infected team secretly attempts to destroy them. Each player knows which team they are on, but does not know which team the other players are on! Who is your teammate and who is your enemy? Can you trust your best friend? And why doesn’t anyone trust you when you tell them you’re one of the good guys?! 
 Roll dice, overcome traumatic events, throw your friends in quarantine when you don’t believe them, and (if you’re Infected) betray everyone at just the right moment to secure victory!

Stellar Prospector is a light game for 3-5 players vying for the chance to run a start-up franchise that prospects rare elements from stars in their planetary system.  The first candidate franchisee to complete five specific delivery missions of specific rare elements to particular planets wins the right to run the franchise (and thus wins the game).

Players start the game with a small amount of money but no ships,  pilots or fuel.  In order to prospect and deliver rare elements, players must hire pilots and buy ships and fuel.  Ships may be bought and pilots hired either at auction or from the shop.  Higher level pilots and ships have a better chance of success but cost more money.  Players make more money either by prospecting and delivering rare elements or bumming around the home base planet doing odd jobs.

Players must learn which stars contain what rare elements through trial-and-error missions and taking note of other players' routes and deliveries.

So players must balance observation with action, knowledge with uncertainty in their race to complete their missions, because star mining is a risky business, with pilot error or ship failure resulting in a fiery end to both.
Party game, a simple trivia game about Britain's first TV soap opera. The guest with the most trivia facts about this programme, wins.

A party game for the more observant guests. Everyone gets to see up to 12 pictures. Then, more pictures, with subtle differences are left where guests can see them, and they must write down what is missing from the second picture version. Whoever gets most right answers durin the evening, wins.

A massive social-trading puzzle game designed for BGG.con 2011. The game was created using 5,000 unique square cards, each with a symbol on each edge and a number in the middle.

Each player is given four cards. The object is to trade cards and then arrange four cards into a highly-valued set, where points are awarded based on matching the colors, fillings, and shapes of the symbols on interior and exterior edges.

Würfel Bohnanza is, as you might suspect, a dice game in the Bohnanza family. Instead of cards, dice give you the beans that you must use to satisfy orders and (eventually) collect "Bohnentalers" (i.e., dollars, bucks, dinero...). The first player to collect thirteen Bohnentalers wins.

At the start of the game, each player receives two order cards, each of which shows six orders; the player tries to complete orders on one card while using the other to cover completed orders. The easiest orders to complete – say, two specific bean types or three beans in any combination of two types – are at the bottom of the card, and the hardest ones – requiring, say, a four-of-a-kind or seven beans with no blue ones – are at the top. Orders must be completed from bottom to top.

On a turn, the active player starts by rolling the seven bean dice, three of which have one combination of beans and four of which have another combination. This player must set aside at least one bean, then she rerolls any remaining dice, setting at least one aside, etc. After at most seven rolls, she completes as many orders as she can, reusing the dice as needed to complete orders. Once a player completes three orders, she can "harvest" the card for one coin. Each additional completed order is worth a coin, up to a maximum of four. When a player harvests the order card, she draws a new card and uses that to record completed orders (possibly on the same turn) on the order card she already had.

In the Bohnanza card game, players trade cards to improve the standing of both parties involved in the trade. In Würfel Bohnanza, the active player doesn't trade dice, but opponents do get to benefit from that player's rolls. After each roll by the active player, all other players can use the dice just rolled – and not dice already set aside – to complete orders on their own cards. Thus, the active player has some incentive not to dawdle too much with her rolls as her opponents might benefit from her turn more than she does.

The game ends as soon as one or more players have collected thirteen Bohnentalers. The player with the most Bohnentalers wins!
